page.title: 08KETTLEWELL - SHEEP FARMING
page.content: Sheep farming is the main farming enterprise in the area. The high land is rough pasture which is only suitable for sheep grazing. The sheep flocks are usually either Dalesbred or Swaledale, but these are crossed with Mashams, Blue-faced Leicester and Suffolk rams for a bigger more marketable lamb. The rams are put to the ewes in November and the ewes then spend most of their pregnancy on the hills. From early January they need supplementary feeding, and before lambing they are brought into the meadows and pastures of the valley bottom. Before the flock is turned back to the higher pastures the lambs are marked, castrated, tailed etc. The ewes are shorn in June and compulsory dipping takes place in July and October. The lambs go to market in August and September.
